{{Refimprove|date=June 2007}} <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:AlliantTechsystemsLogo.png|right|150px|Alliant Techsystems logo]] --> [[Image:NAVSEA logo.jpg|thumb|right|160px]] [[Image:Federal Laboratory Consortium.jpg|thumb|right]] '''Allegany Ballistics Laboratory''' ('''ABL''') located in [[Rocket Center, West Virginia]], is a diverse [[factory|industrial complex]] employing some 1,000 people across {{convert|1628|acre|km2}}. The facility is a member of the [[Federal Laboratory Consortium]] and is operated by [[Alliant Techsystems]] (ATK) under contract with the [[Naval Sea Systems Command]] (NAVSEA).
== Current operation ==
The ABL facility is a manufacturer of advanced [[composite materials|composite structures]] for the [[F-22 Raptor]] and other aerospace projects. ATK also operates 6 of 11 known [[advanced fiber placement|advanced fiber placement machines]]. In addition the site produces about 80 military products, including: [[30 mm caliber|30mm shells]] for [[AH-64 Apache|Apache helicopters]], [[training grenades]], [[Proximity fuze|fuze-proximity sensors]], [[Mortar (weapon)|mortars]] and [[warhead]]s, and [[tank ammunition]].
Also on the site is the Robert C. Byrd Hilltop Office Complex and the [[Robert C. Byrd Institute]] for Advanced Flexible Manufacturing. At the Robert C. Byrd Complex on the hill companies have rented space to do secure research, among them [[IBM]] (which recently acquired [https://web.archive.org/web/20120107084722/http://www.nisc-llc.com/ National Interest Security Company]) who is digitizing data on hurricane cleanup, [[avian influenza]], and weather records.
== History ==
ABL was established in 1944 on the site of a former ammunitions plant on land owned by the Army. After World War II, the plant was transferred to the [[Office of Scientific Research and Development]] and was involved in building propulsion devices and engines for the solid-rocket industry.
Later in the decade, ownership of ABL was transferred to the Navy office of [[Naval Sea Systems Command]]. Since 1946 it was operated by the [[Hercules Powder Company]].<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/missilesrockets8919unse#page/n325/mode/2up ''Missiles and Rockets''], May 29, 1961, p. 113.</ref> In 1956 when it was producing [[Altair (rocket stage)|Altair]] rocket stages for [[Vanguard rocket]]s, ABL was, "A subsidiary of the Navy operated by the Hercules Powder Company."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://seds.org/archive/spaceviews/9712/articles3.html |title=Vanguard: America's Answer to Sputnik |last=LePage |first=Andrew J. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808190710/http://www.seds.org/archive/spaceviews/9712/articles3.html |archivedate=2009-08-08 |df= }}</ref> The Navy now contracts out operation of the facility to [[Alliant Techsystems|ATK (Alliant Techsystems)]], a $3.4 billion corporation based in [[Edina, Minnesota]].
In 1998, ATK's Conventional Munitions Group was selected by [[Lockheed Martin Aeronautical Systems]] to produce the fiber-placed composite pivot shaft assembly for the [[F-22 Raptor]] air-dominance fighter. Work on the production program was performed at Alliant's automated fiber placement production facility at the Allegany Ballistics Laboratory before the production of F-22 aircraft ended in 2012. The fiber placement facility was constructed as part of a $177 million renovation and restoration program funded by the U.S. Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA), which owns the Allegany Ballistics Laboratory. <ref>[http://atk.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=165 Alliant Techsystems Selected by Lockheed Martin Aeronautical Systems to Produce Composite Pivot Shaft for F-22 Fighter]</ref>
== Local Perception ==
As for the ecological impact, it is believed the facility contributes greatly to the pollution of the adjacent [[North Branch Potomac River]]. While this is unsupported, the company does have numerous runoff sites.{{fact|date=November 2018}} Also, the groundwater in the surrounding community has been verified to contain many contaminants, although actions have since been taken to reduce these contaminants, and are part of a constant monitoring process.<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/reg3hwmd/npl/WV0170023691.htm West Virginia, Allegany Ballistics Laboratory (US Navy) Site, Current Site Information (NPL Pad) | Mid-Atlantic Superfund | US EPA<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511101757/http://epa.gov/reg3hwmd/npl/WV0170023691.htm |date=2009-05-11 }}</ref>

{{notability|Places|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox business park | name = Business Park Skejby | image = | image_size = | caption = | location = [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]] | address = | coordinates = | opening_date = {{Start date|2013}} | closing_date = | developer = | construction_cost = | manager = Arne Vesterdal (board director) | owner = cooperatively owned | architect = | number_of_tenants = 150 | number_of_workers = 20,000 | size = | parking = yes | website = {{URL|http://businessparkskejby.dk/}} }} '''Business Park Skejby''' is a large [[business park]] in the northern district of [[Aarhus N]], in the city of Aarhus, Denmark.
Business Park Skejby was officially created in 2013 and stretches north from the neighbourhood of Christiansbjerg to Skejby and is bounded by the major roads of [[Ring 2 (Aarhus)|Ring 2]] and [[Randersvej]].<ref>BSP: [http://businessparkskejby.dk/Om-BPS.aspx A map of Business Park Skejby]</ref> Most of the businesses and institutions within the park area were constructed several decades ago.
==Description== Apart from small and large businesses, the business park area is also home to the smaller business park of Agro Food Park, a large number of educational facilities and a few residential areas as well. Major institutions, most of which predates 2013, includes:
* [[Aarhus University Hospital|The New University Hospital]] (DNU) * [[NRGi]] headquarters. NRGi is a large Danish coop energy company.<ref>NRGi: [http://nrgiinfo.dk/nrgiinfo/om-nrgi/om-nrgi/nrgi-huset/ NRGi-huset]</ref> * [[Vestas Wind Systems]], headquarters * [[IBM]], Danish headquarters * [[Olympus Corporation|Olympus]] * [[Danmarks Radio]], Jutland department * [[Danish School of Journalism]], the Aarhus campus of the Danish School of Media and Journalism. * [[VIA University College]], Campus Aarhus N * [[SOSU aarhus]] educational centre for social- and healthcareworkers * [[INCUBA Science Park]], headquarters * [[Agro Food Park]] * [[Aarhus Skøjtehal]], an indoor ice skating rink * [[Aarhus Academy]] * [[Aarhus Tech]], main campus
Landmarks for the area includes ''Aarhus Vandtårn'', a former water tower in red brick with a bright green copper roof, the nature site of [[Vestereng]] - a former military training ground -, and the old village of [[Skejby]] with an old white-washed village church.
Business Park Skejby has its headquarters outside the park in the library and culture centre of [[Dokk1]] at the harbourfront.
== Transportation == The business park is located at the outer ring road of [[Ring 2 (Aarhus)|Ring 2]] (Hasle Ringvej) and the intercity motorway of Randersvej, with easy access to all of Aarhus.
Since December 2017, the business park has been connected to the inner city, including the business park headquarters and the central station, by the [[Aarhus light rail]], an electric tram system.

{{spanish name|Urbizo|Solís}} '''Carlos Urbizo Solís''' is a Honduran politician and businessman. He was a candidate to the Vice-Presidency for the [[National Party of Honduras|National Party]].<ref name=elmundo>{{cite web|author=Laura Rivera |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2009/08/05/internacional/1249486548.html |title=Honduras: Un país fracturado |language=Spanish |publisher=El Mundo |date=5 August 2009 |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2007 he denied having bank accounts with debts and having given political favours to banks, he declared this after having appeared on a list of people allegedly having done so.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.laprensa.hn/sucesos/680533-97/no-tengo-ninguna-cuenta-pendiente-carlos-urbizo |title="No tengo ninguna cuenta pendiente": Carlos Urbizo |language=Spanish |publisher=La Prensa |date=29 January 2007 |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2009 he supported the rule of President [[Roberto Micheletti]], who was internationally unrecognized, and supported the legal measures against former President [[Manuel Zelaya]].<ref name=elmundo/>
Urbizo regards the issue of poverty in Honduras related to the political and economic system. Which he views as anti-democratic and anti-capitalistic.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.hondurasweekly.com/national/item/16783-honduras-poverty-rate-hits-69 |title=Honduras' Poverty Rate Hits 69% |publisher=Honduras Weekly |date= |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> In 2014 he complained over business opportunities in Honduras, laying the blame with corrupt politicians.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gerzon Padilla |url=http://www.radiohrn.hn/l/noticias/urbizo-sol%C3%ADs-pretender-que-el-gobierno-maneje-negocios-es-como-ponerle-alas-un-burro |title=Urbizo Solís: "Pretender que el gobierno maneje negocios es como ponerle alas a un burro" |publisher=Radio HRN |date=26 March 2014 |accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>

'''Cornelis Bernardus Maria (Cees) van Riel''' (born 15 June 1951) is a Dutch [[organizational theorist]], consultant, and Professor of Corporate Communication at [[Rotterdam School of Management]] and Director of the Corporate Communication Centre at the [[Erasmus University]], known for his work in the area of corporate communication<ref>Gioia, Dennis A., Majken Schultz, and Kevin G. Corley. "Organizational identity, image, and adaptive instability." ''Academy of management Review'' 25.1 (2000): 63-81.</ref> and reputation management.<ref>Balmer, John MT. "Corporate identity, corporate branding and corporate marketing-seeing through the fog." ''European journal of marketing'' 35.3/4 (2001): 248-291.</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Tilburg]] and raised in [[Eindhoven]], Van Riel studied Mass Communication at the [[Radboud University Nijmegen]] from 1973 to 1973, receiving his BA in Political Science, another BA in Economic History and his MA in Mass Communication. In 1986 he obtained his PhD in communication at [[Erasmus University Rotterdam]] for the doctoral dissertation entitled "Overheidsvoorlichting en Intermediaire kaders" (Government Information and Intermediary Staff).
In November 1993 Van Riel was appointed Professor of Corporate Communication at [[Rotterdam School of Management]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsm.nl/portal/page/portal/RSM2/attachments/pdf2/Curriculum%20Vitae_CeesvanRiel%20(2).pdf |title=Curriculum Vitae |last=Van Riel|first=Cees |publisher=Rotterdam School of Management |format=PDF |accessdate=October 27, 2009 }} </ref> He is also Director of the Corporate Communication Centre and Vice Chairman of the Reputation Institute. He was founding father of the Master of Science in Corporate Communication<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsm.nl/home/master/executive_and_specialised_masters/corporate_communications |title=Master of Science in Corporate Communication |publisher=Rotterdam School of Management |accessdate=October 27, 2009 }} </ref> (MSc degree programme) at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. This was the first programme of its kind, offered at a university level ([[Master Degree]]), in the world. He
Van Riel has worked as a communication strategy consultant for a variety of companies in Europe. He is also the Editor-in-Chief together with Charles Fombrun of the Corporate Reputation Review.<ref>{{cite web|author=Corporate Reputation Review |url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/crr/index.html |title=Corporate Reputation Review |publisher=Palgrave-journals.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/crr/index.html |title=Corporate Reputation Review |publisher=Palgrave |accessdate=October 27, 2009}}</ref>
Van Riel received several awards. The article "The Impact of Employee Communication and Perceived External Prestige on Organizational Identification" with co-authors [[Ale Smidts]] and Ad Th.H. Pruyn won the ERIM Top Article Award 2002.<ref>[http://www.erim.eur.nl/ERIM/About/erim_awards_programme/Top_Article_Award ERIM Top Article Award 2002] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724153449/http://www.erim.eur.nl/ERIM/About/erim_awards_programme/Top_Article_Award |date=July 24, 2011 }}</ref> His 2003 books ''Fame & Fortune'' authored with Charles Fombrun received the [[Erasmus Research Institute of Management]] (ERIM) Impact on Management Practice Award 2006.<ref>[http://www.erim.eur.nl/ERIM/About/erim_awards_programme/Impact_Award ERIM Impact awards] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152905/http://www.erim.eur.nl/ERIM/About/erim_awards_programme/Impact_Award |date=July 24, 2011 }}</ref> In 2011 Van Riel received the 2011 Pathfinder Award, the highest academic honor bestowed by he Institute for Public Relations (IPR)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.instituteforpr.org/ |title=Institute for Public Relations (IPR) |publisher=Instituteforpr.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-19}}</ref> for his contribution to research in the field of corporate reputation and strategic alignment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.instituteforpr.org/releases/corporate-reputation-research-pioneer-to-receive-ipr-pathfinder-award/ |title=Corporate Reputation Research Pioneer To Receive IPR Pathfinder Award |publisher=Instituteforpr.org |date=2011-10-26 |accessdate=2013-12-19}}</ref>
== Work == From his academic research and studies, the most applied models are: RepTrak Model and RepTrak Alignment Monitor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allesoverinternalbranding.nl/2009/03/drie-vragen-aan-cees-van-riel/ |title=Drie vragen aan Cees van Riel « allesoverinternalbranding |publisher=Allesoverinternalbranding.nl |date=2009-03-06 |accessdate=2013-12-19}}</ref>
=== RepTrak model === The RepTrak Model is a tool that tracks 23 key performance indicators grouped around 7 reputation dimensions that research has proven to be effective in getting stakeholders to support the company. The beating heart of the RepTrak Model is the Pulse. The RepTrak Pulse measures the health of a company's overall reputation with consumers. The RepTrak Pulse score is based on four statements: the ''esteem'', ''good feeling'', ''trust'', and ''admiration'' that consumers feel towards a company. The results of this study are published world-wide through [[Forbes]].com as well as through local partners in the 27 countries included in the study.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/05/21/reputation-institute-survey-lead-citizen-cx_sm_0521methodology.html | work=Forbes | title=Company Methodology | date=May 21, 2007}}</ref> {{buzzword|date=April 2017}} === Reputation Institute === Van Riel co-founded the [[Reputation Institute]] in 1997. This Institute has functioned as a private research and consulting organisation. Its mission is to advance knowledge about corporate reputation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wn.com/cees_van_riel |title=Cees Van Riel |publisher=Wn.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-19}}</ref> and help companies create economic value by implementing coherent reputing strategies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reputationinstitute.com/about/index |title=Co-founder |last=Van Riel|first=Cees |publisher=Reputation Institute |accessdate=October 27, 2009 }}</ref>
== Publications == Cees van Riel published several books and articles about corporate communication. Books, a selection: * Van Riel, Cees BM, ''Principles of Corporate Communication''. Prentice Hall, 1992. * Van Riel, Cees BM, ''Identiteit en Imago,'' 1992. * Fombrun, Charles J., and Cees BM Van Riel. ''Fame & fortune: How successful companies build winning reputations.'' FT Press, 2004. * Van Riel, Cees BM, and Charles J. Fombrun. ''Essentials of corporate communication: Implementing practices for effective reputation management.'' Routledge, 2007.
Articles, a selection: * Fombrun, Charles, and Cees Van Riel. "[http://repub.eur.nl/pub/12136/TheReputationalLandscape_1997.pdf The reputational landscape]." ''Corporate reputation review'' (1997): 1-16. * van Riel, Cees BM, and John MT Balmer. "[http://repub.eur.nl/pub/12137/CorporateIdentity_1997.pdf Corporate identity: the concept, its measurement and management]." ''European journal of marketing'' 31.5/6 (1997): 340-355. * Jo Hatch, Mary, C.B.M. van Riel, and Majken Schultz. "[http://fcis.vdu.lt/~n.klebanskaja@evf.vdu.lt/FOV1-000A97C7/FOV1-000AA1AB/0070310502.pdf Relations between organizational culture, identity and image]." European Journal of marketing 31.5/6 (1997): 356-365. * [[Smidts, Ale]], Ad Th H. Pruyn, and Cees BM Van Riel. "[http://repub.eur.nl/pub/10/erimrs20000321133141.pdf The impact of employee communication and perceived external prestige on organizational identification]." ''Academy of Management journal'' 44.5 (2001): 1051-1062.

'''Citilink''' is a [[Low-cost carrier|low-cost airline]] headquartered in [[Jakarta]], Indonesia. It was established in 2001 as a low-cost brand of [[Garuda Indonesia]], set up to operate shuttle services between Indonesian cities. Since 30 July 2012, Citilink has officially operated as a separate subsidiary of Garuda Indonesia, operating with its own callsign, airline codes, logo and uniform.<ref name=Spinoff>{{cite web|title=July 30, 2012 – Citilink officially separates from Garuda today|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/07/30/citilink-officially-separates-garuda-today.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409235135/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/07/30/citilink-officially-separates-garuda-today.html|archivedate=April 9, 2013|df=}}</ref> Its main hub is [[Juanda International Airport]], [[Surabaya]], [[East Java]].<ref name="FI">{{cite news | title= Directory: World Airlines | work= [[Flight International]] | page= 66 | date= 2007-04-03}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Citilink Fokker F-28-4000 Fellowship Sim.jpg|thumb|Citilink [[Fokker F28 Fellowship]] in 2003]] [[File:Citilink Boeing 737-300 MRD-3.jpg|thumb|Citilink [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-300]] at [[Juanda International Airport]] in 2005]] Garuda Indonesia established Citilink as a low-cost brand in 2001 and operations commenced on 16 July that year with two [[Fokker F28 Fellowship]]s transferred from the mainline fleet. Initial operations were from Surabaya on the island of Java to destinations not served by Garuda Indonesia's mainline fleet: Yogyakarta (also on Java); Balikpapan on the island of Borneo and [[Tarakan, North Kalimantan]], just off Borneo's coast; and Makassar on the island of Sulawesi. By the end of 2001 Garuda had transferred five F28s to Citilink. In 2004 Citilink was serving ten destinations and Garuda began to replace the F28s with [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-300s]]. In 2008 Garuda temporarily suspended operations of Citilink, relaunching the brand in January 2009 after replacing the remaining Fokker F28s with more modern aircraft. In July 2010 Citilink operations were being conducted by two Boeing 737-300s and a [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-400]].
===Spinoff and expansion plans=== In May 2011 Garuda announced plans for a spin-off of Citilink. The new business plan was for Citilink to become a separate business entity in the first quarter of 2012 with a full brand overhaul for the airline, including a new livery design; new website; a new cabin interior design and cabin crew uniforms; and new advertising and marketing strategies.<ref name="thejakartapost.com">[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/08/05/garuda-announces-new-plans-citilink-ahead-spin.html Garuda announces new plans for Citilink ahead of spin-off | The Jakarta Post<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> An integral part of this plan was for Citilink to secure 25 new [[Airbus A320 family|Airbus A320s]] and utilising these new and more economical aircraft to expand into a significant regional low-cost carrier with the anticipation that by 2015, Citilink would contribute 30 percent of Garuda Indonesia's revenue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pikiran-rakyat.com/node/154116|title=25 New Airbus 320s|work=pikiran-rakyat.com|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pikiran-rakyat.com/node/154113|title=2015, Citilink Contribute 30% Garuda Indonesia's Revenue|work=pikiran-rakyat.com|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref>
After obtaining an [[Air Operator's Certificate]] in August 2012, Citilink had carried 8 million passengers by the end of 2013 and was running at a load factor of 85 percent and an On Time Arrival rate of 87 percent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ekbis.rmol.co/read/2014/01/15/140001/Citilink-Terbangkan-8-Juta-Penumpang-Sejak-2012- |title=Citilink Terbangkan 8 Juta Penumpang Sejak 2012 |trans-title=Citilink Flies 8 Million Passengers Since 2012 |author=Widya Victoria |date=January 15, 2014}}</ref> In May 2015 the airline's fleet consisted of four Boeing 737-300s, four [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-500s]] and thirty-four Airbus A320s.

== Fleet == [[File:CTV A320 F-WWDJ!6207 24jul14 LFBO.jpg|thumb|One of Citilink's Airbus A320s, prior to delivery at [[Toulouse Airport]]]] [[File:PK-GTC at CGK.jpg|thumb|One of Citilink's [[Airbus A320neo]] at [[Soekarno–Hatta International Airport]]]]
As of August 2018, Citilink operates the following aircraft:<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.planespotters.net/airline/Citilink|title=Citilink Fleet Details and History|publisher=Planespotters.net|date=30 July 2018|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> <center> {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse;text-align:center" |+ Citilink fleet |- ! Aircraft ! In service ! Orders ! Passengers ! Notes |- |[[Airbus A320 family|Airbus A320-200]] |44 |— |180 |Older leased A320s are to be retired and replaced by A320neos |- |[[Airbus A320neo family|Airbus A320neo]] |8 |27 |180 | |- |[[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-500]] |2 |— |96 | |- !Total !54 !27 !colspan=3| |} </center>
On 9 August 2011, Garuda Indonesia finalised an order for 25 Airbus A320 aircraft with options for 25 more, making the airline a new customer for the Airbus single aisle aircraft type.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.airbus.com/presscentre/pressreleases/press-release-detail/detail/garuda-indonesia-finalises-order-for-25-a320-family-aircraft|title=Garuda Indonesia finalises order for 25 A320 Family aircraft |publisher=Airbus |date=9 August 2011}}</ref> The order consisted of 15 Airbus A320s and 10 Airbus A320neos, with five aircraft expected to be delivered each year between 2014 and 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pasarmodal.inilah.com/read/detail/1761754/garuda-teken-pembelian-25-pesawat-a320-family |title=Garuda Teken Pembelian 25 Pesawat A320 Family |date=August 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.aviationnews.eu/2011/08/09/garuda-indonesia-finalises-order-for-25-a320-family-aircraft/citilink-a320neo/ Garuda Indonesia finalises order for 25 A320 Family aircraft Citilink A320neo – INTERNATIONAL AVIATION NEWS<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524154655/http://www.aviationnews.eu/2011/08/09/garuda-indonesia-finalises-order-for-25-a320-family-aircraft/citilink-a320neo/ |date=2013-05-24 }}</ref> The fleet upgrade program was valued at around $2.13 billion.
By late 2011, Garuda Indonesia was seeking more used A320s in preparation for the launch of proposed international Citilink services in 2012.<ref name="thejakartapost.com"/> In September 2011 the airline announced plans to introduce four more used A320s to enter into service between October 2011 and February 2012.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
In December 2012, Citilink placed an order for 25 [[ATR 72|ATR 72-600s]] with options for 25 more.<ref name="aviationweek1">{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_12_27_2012_p0-532247.xml&p=1 |title=Indonesia's Citilink Ordering 25 ATR 72-600s |publisher=Aviationweek.com |date=2012-12-27 |accessdate=2013-01-27}}</ref> This was Citilink's first direct order to a manufacturer. A direct order for 25 additional A320neos followed in January 2013, bringing up the total order to 35.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.airbus.com/presscentre/pressreleases/press-release-detail/detail/citilink-orders-25-airbus-a320neo/ |title=Citilink orders 25 Airbus A320neo |publisher=Airbus |date= 25 January 2013|accessdate=2013-01-27}}</ref>
Citilink's first A320, a second-hand aircraft, arrived in late June 2011 and entered into service on 16 September 2011, linking Jakarta with Balikpapan, Banjarmasin and Medan.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
In September 2013, Citilink cancelled its plan to operate ATR 72s as its parent company Garuda Indonesia took over the order, citing commercial reasons.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
==Services== ===Cabin=== Citilink aircraft cabins have standard configuration of 180 seats. In July 2018, Citilink introduced "Green Zone" programme.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/travel/2018/07/19/citilink-introduces-green-zone-facility.html|title=Citilink introduces Green Zone facility|publisher=The Jakarta Post|date=19 July 2018|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> Seats on the first five rows and emergency window exit rows are named green seats, while the rest are named regular seats. Passengers wanting to book or request a green seat or specific regular seat during booking or check-in will be charged for a certain fee. Additional benefits include free snacks, drinks, and insurance.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.citilink.co.id/en/green-zone|title=Green Zone|publisher=Citilink|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
==Accidents and incidents== ===Citilink Flight 800 incident=== On 28 December 2016, a video taken by a passenger aboard Citilink Flight 800, a flight from [[Juanda International Airport]] in [[Surabaya]] to [[Soekarno-Hatta International Airport]] in [[Jakarta]] went viral after it purportedly showed a drunk pilot making a "bizarre announcement" before take off. Several passengers immediately reported the incident to the airline's headquarters. The crew of the flight quickly removed the drunk pilot from the cockpit. Due to the incident, the flight was delayed for an hour.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Pilot Ngelantur di Pesawat, Penerbangan Citilink Sempat Delay|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3381991/pilot-ngelantur-di-pesawat-penerbangan-citilink-sempat-delay|publisher=Detik|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>
Citilink immediately took action by [[firing|sacking]] the pilot involved in the incident and issuing letters of apology to affected passengers.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Penjelasan Lengkap Citilink Soal Pilot Ngelantur Jelang Terbang|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3382103/penjelasan-lengkap-citilink-soal-pilot-ngelantur-jelang-terbang|publisher=Detik|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> As the video went viral, the incident brought negative scrutiny on the already reeling Indonesian aviation industry, sparking massive public outcry. The incident was widely reported in the media, with several international news organizations covering the incident.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Shocking CCTV footage shows 'drunk' pilot stumbling through security before being fired when he 'tried to fly a plane with 154 passengers on board'|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/2502956/shocking-cctv-footage-shows-drunk-pilot-stumbling-through-security-before-being-fired-when-he-tried-to-fly-a-plane-with-154-passengers-on-board/|publisher=The Sun|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> The Indonesian Transport Ministry apologized publicly to the Indonesian people due to the incident. The ministry later added that the pilot had undergone drug testing, conducted by the Indonesian National Narcotic Agency.<ref>{{citeweb|title= Kemenhub Minta Maaf Soal Pilot Ngelantur dan Minta Citilink Tindak Tegas|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3383906/kemenhub-minta-maaf-soal-pilot-ngelantur-dan-minta-citilink-tindak-tegas|publisher=Detik|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>
Another video, captured from cameras at the airport security checkpoint, later surfaced and went viral. The video showed the drunk pilot becoming jittery and even nearly losing his balance during the security check.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Allegedly drunk pilot filmed stumbling through security|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/12/30/drunk-pilot-indonesia/96007366/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> Police investigated the video, resulting in the Indonesian Transport Ministry sending Citilink its very first warning.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Ada Pilot Mabuk, Kemhub Layangkan Peringatan Pertama ke Citilink|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3384785/ada-pilot-mabuk-kemhub-layangkan-peringatan-pertama-ke-citilink|publisher=Detik|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>
In the aftermath of the incident, the CEO of Citilink, Albert Burhan, resigned.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Pilotnya Diduga Mabuk, CEO Citilink Mengundurkan Diri|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3384597/pilotnya-diduga-mabuk-ceo-citilink-mengundurkan-diri|publisher=Detik|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> The operational director of Citilink, Hadinoto Soedigno, also resigned in response to the incident.<ref>{{citeweb|title=Two Indonesian airline executives resign after footage shows pilot staggering to plane|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-12-31/indonesian-airline-executives-resign-after-pilot-video-released/8155374|publisher=ABC|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref> Indonesian Transport Minister Budi Karya praised their actions due to the incident, stating that they were "very gentle".<ref>{{citeweb|title=CEO Citilink Mundur, Menhub: Sangat Gentle!|url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3385076/ceo-citilink-mundur-menhub-sangat-gentle|publisher=Detik|accessdate=22 January 2017}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} [[File:KCMG Jpegfile.jpg|thumb|right|120px|'''KCMG insignia''']] '''Sir Ewen Cameron''' [[Order of St Michael and St George|KCMG]] (23 June 1841, [[Aberdeen]] – 10 December 1908, [[London]]) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[merchant banker]] and [[chartered accountant]] of the [[Victorian era|late 19th century]], who rose to be [[chairman]] of [[Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation|Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank]] in [[City of London|London]]. He played a key role in arranging loans from the [[Rothschild family]] to the [[Empire of Japan]] during the [[Russo-Japanese War]].{{Citation| last = Smethurst| first = Richard| url =https://www.rothschildarchive.org/materials/ar2006japan.pdf| title = Takahasi Korekiyo, the Rothschilds and the Russo-Japanese War, 1904–1907| format = PDF| accessdate =26 March 2017}}{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1191155/Claims-David-Cameron-30m-fortune-sit-uneasily-taxpayers-So-truth-money.html| title=Claims that David Cameron has a £30m fortune sit uneasily with taxpayers. So what is the truth about his money?| author=Geoffrey Levy, Christian Gysin| work=Daily Mail (online)| date=5 June 2009 | accessdate=14 July 2013 | location=London}}The Guardian: [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2012/apr/20/david-cameron-jersey-panama-geneva David Cameron's family fortune: the Jersey, Panama and Geneva connection | Politics], The Guardian, 26 April 2012 ==Early life and family== [[File:Easter Muckovie Farm trigpoint - geograph.org.uk - 377530.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Muckovie, Inverness-shire]] Cameron was born in [[Inverness-shire]], [[Scotland]], the eldest child of William Cameron (b. 4 February 1806 at [[List of listed buildings in Boleskine And Abertarff, Highland|Abertarff]])[http://www.scottishchurches.org.uk/sites/site/id/4361/name/Abbey+Church+Boleskine+and+Abertarff+Highland www.scottishchurches.org.uk] of [[Inverness|Upper Muckovie]], near [[Culloden, Highland|Culloden]] by [[Croy, Highland|Croy]],[http://www.strathnairnheritage.org.uk/index.asp?pageid=543358 www.strathnairnheritage.org.uk] by his wife (m. 16 June 1840), Catherine Cameron (b. 22 January 1809), daughter of Ewen Cameron (1775–1842), a farmer and [[kinship|kinsman]] of [[Tomchrasky]], [[Glen Moriston]] and [[Clan Donald|Helen McDonnell]] (1776–1861).[http://www.clan-cameron.org.au/pedigree.php?personID=I34514&tree=cameron1 Pedigree for Ewan Cameron, Cameron Genealogies]http://www.wargs.com/noble/cameron.html [[File:The Caledonian - geograph.org.uk - 885545.jpg|thumb|right|135px|Caledonian Bank, former HQ in Aberdeen]] ==Career== In 1859, Cameron joined the [[Bank of Scotland|Caledonian Bank]] in [[Aberdeen]] as an accounting clerk. After qualifying as a [[chartered accountant]] he was posted to the [[Bank of Hindustan, China and Japan]] before being transferred to [[Hong Kong]] in 1866. His abilities, described as "remarkable" by ''[[The Times]]'', helped him to land a senior position with the newly formed [[Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation|Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank]] after the Bank of Hindustan went into liquidation. A [[chartered accountant]], Cameron became principal agent to the [[Calcutta]] branch of HSBC, following which he acted as [[Branch (banking)|manager]] of its [[Shanghai]] branch, where he served until 1890. Cameron's success in reorganizing the bank was rewarded by his appointment as a [[director (business)|director]] before he returned to Britain, where he became chairman of the bank in the [[City of London]]. Cameron was appointed [[Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George|KCMG]] at the end of 1901 for his "services to overseas banking",''[[The Times]]'', Obituary, 11 December 1908 and was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society]] (FRGS) in February 1902.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Court Circular|day_of_week=Wednesday |date=12 February 1902 |page_number=9 |issue=36689| }} During 1904 Cameron and other leading London financiers, including [[John Baring, 2nd Baron Revelstoke|Lord Revelstoke]] of [[Barings Bank|Baring Bros.]], Arthur Francis Levita and [[Koch family|W. M. Koch]] of [[Panmure Gordon]] (Levita's daughter Enid would later marry Cameron's grandson Ewen Donald Cameron in 1930), [[Marcus Samuel, 1st Viscount Bearsted|Sir Marcus Samuel]] (later Viscount Bearsted) of [[Samuel Samuel & Co]] and [[Royal Dutch Shell]], [[Sir Carl Meyer 1st Baronet|Sir Carl Meyer]], and [[Otto Kahn]], took part in negotiations with the [[Bank of Japan|Japanese central banker]] [[Takahashi Korekiyo]] (later [[Prime Minister of Japan]]) for the selling of war bonds to finance the Japanese war effort during the [[Russo-Japanese War]]. ==Marriage and issue== In 1878, Cameron married Josephine Elizabeth (born at [[Redenhall with Harleston|Shotford]], [[Norfolk]] in 1857), daughter of John Houchen of [[Thetford]], [[Norfolk]] ([[Wereham]], Norfolk, c. 1818 - Thetford, Norfolk, 6 October 1898''[[The Times]]'' 11 Oct 1898, 1A) by his wife (m. [[St James's]], [[Westminster]], 29 November 1845''[[The Gentleman's Magazine]]'' Jan. 1846, p. 88) Susannah Vautier ([[Stanton, Suffolk|Stanton]], [[Suffolk]], c. 1819 - Thetford, Norfolk, 1859), by whom he had five children. His eldest son, Ewen Allan Cameron, [[senior partner]] in [[Panmure Gordon & Co.]]''[[The Times]]'', "Committee for Bondholders", 2 November 1935 and member of the [[Council of Foreign Bondholders]]''[[The Times]]'', "Council of Foreign Bondholders", 24 July 1936 (who died 14 November 1937 in [[Vienna]]''[[The Times]]'', "Deaths", 16 November 1937) was the great-grandfather of [[David Cameron]], [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party Leader]] (2005–2016) and [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] (2010–2016).[http://www.clan-cameron.org.au/pedigree.php?personID=I34518&tree=cameron1 Pedigree for Ewen Donald Cameron], Cameron Genealogies[http://www.thepeerage.com/p17890.htm#i178900 Ewen Donald Cameron], thePeerage.com ==Death== After suffering bouts of ill health in 1903 and at the end of 1904, Sir Ewen retired in February 1905 and later died at home in [[Hampstead]] [[NW postcode area|NW3]] on 10 December 1908 at the age of 67. ==Coat of arms== {{Infobox COA wide |image = |imagesize = |bannerimage = |badgeimage = |notes = By matriculation with [[Court of the Lord Lyon|Lord Lyon King of Arms]] |year_adopted = 1905 |crest = A Hand Proper grasping a Sprig of Crowberries also Proper |torse = |helm = A Knight's [[Helmet (heraldry)|helm]] |escutcheon = [[Gules]] three [[Bar (heraldry)|Bars]] [[Or (heraldry)|Or]] in [[Chief (heraldry)|chief]] four [[Bezant]]s of the Second |supporters = |compartment = |motto = ''Bi Dhichioll'' ([[English language|Eng]]: ''By best endeavours'')

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2007}} The {{nihongo|'''Financial Instruments and Exchange Act'''|金融商品取引法|Kin'yū shōhin torihiki-hō}}, promulgated on June 14, 2006, is the main [[statute]] codifying [[securities law]] and regulating securities companies in Japan.
The law provides for:
* Registration and regulation of [[broker dealer]]s and their [[registered representative]]s * [[Corporation#Financial disclosure|Disclosure]] obligations applicable to public companies, [[investment trust]]s and similar entities * [[Tender offer]] rules * Disclosure obligations applicable to large shareholders in public companies * [[Internal control]]s in public companies; in this role the law is often referred to as '''J-SOX''', a reference to the American [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]] (SOX).
==J-SOX provisions== The internal control portions of the FIEA were largely enacted in response to [[corporate scandal]]s such as the Kanebo, [[Livedoor]], and [[Murakami Fund scandal|Murakami Fund]] episodes.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}
The Internal Control Committee of the Business Accounting Council of the Japanese Financial Services Agency provided final Implementation Guidance for Management Assessment and Audit of Internal Controls over Financial Reporting (ICFR) in February 2007. The Implementation Guidance provides details to Japanese companies on how to implement a Management Assessment of Internal Control over Financial Reporting as required under the Financial Instruments and Exchange Law.
The Financial Instruments and Exchange Act became effective in April 2008 for roughly 3,800 companies listed in Japan, along with their foreign subsidiaries.
Forrester Research lists the following challenges and differences between J-SOX and SOX: * Professional services. Japan has fewer than 10% of the number of qualified accountants than the US. * Independence of auditors. While the concept of auditor independence exists in the Japanese market similar to the US, many Japanese firms can and will rely on the influence and recommendations of their audit firms. * Audit automation is critical. With the extreme shortage of auditors compared to US per capita numbers, this shortage will increase the requirement and necessity for process efficiency in the internal audit process and software that can support these processes. * Support of IT governance. In the November guidance regarding the scope of the J-SOX process, it is clear that IT controls are a central point of focus for J-SOX

{{Infobox company | name = Forum for International Trade Training (FITT) | logo = Forum_for_International_Trade_Training_(FITT)_Logo.jpg | type = Non-profit | founded = 1992 | founder = Canadian Government and Private Sector | hq_location_city = Ottawa, ON | key_people = Caroline Tompkins, CAE, CITP, President and CEO | industry = Import-export training and certification; international trade training and certification | num_employees = 10 | homepage = http://www.fittfortrade.com/ | location_country = [[Canada]] }} The '''Forum for International Trade Training''' ('''FITT''') is "a not-for-profit organization that offers [[international business]] training, resources and [[professional certification]] to individuals and businesses."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/about-us|title=About Us|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
FITT offers the FITTskills international trade training program, a series of 8 courses for global business professionals can that can be taken either online or in a classroom setting through educational partners.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/fittskills-online-courses|title=FITTskills Online Courses|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/online-instructor-led-courses|title=Online & Instructor-Led Courses|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-09}}</ref> FITTskills students receive the FITT Certificate in International Trade after completing four of the courses, and the FITT Diploma in International Trade after completing all eight courses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/credentials|title=Credentials|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref>
The organization also offers the Certified International Trade Professional designation, also trademarked as the FITT International Business Professional designation in the U.S. and Europe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/fibp-details|title=FIBP Details|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> It is often referred to as the CITP|FIBP designation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/certification|title=Professional International Business Certification CITP {{!}} FIBP|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> In French, it is referred to as the Professionnel accrédité en commerce international (PACI|FPAI) designation.
FITT's strategic partners are [[Export Development Canada|Export Development Canada (EDC)]], [[Global Affairs Canada|Global Affairs Canada (GAC)]] and the [[World Trade Centers Association]].
== History == In the late 1980s, Dieter Hollweck, began the planning towards a new organization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tradeready.ca/2014/inside-stories/story-began-us-forum-international-trade-training-fitt/|title=The story of how it all began for us, the Forum for International Trade Training (FITT) - Trade Ready|website=Trade Ready|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> FITT was then incorporated in 1992 as part of Canada’s sector council initiative.
FITT first launched its FITTskills training program in 1993, which is now in its sixth edition, with the seventh edition being launched in early 2017. In 1996, it also launched the Prior Learning Assessment and Recognition (PLAR) process to allow business professionals to use their previous work and educational experience to earn FITTskills credits. FITTskills courses were first offered online in 1999, which continues today.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/about-us/milestones|title=Milestones|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
In 2001, FITT began to accredit [[academic institution]]s and organizations already offering international business courses to offer FITTskills courses. There are currently over 43 educational partners in Canada, China, Colombia, Malaysia, Romania and the UK, offering FITTskills courses in a classroom setting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fittfortrade.com/instructorled-courses|title=Instructor Led Courses|website=Forum for International Trade Training (FITT)|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref>
FITT's CITP designation was first offered in 1998, and the competency requirements were revised in 2006 and again in 2016. Since 2009, it has also been trademarked as the FIBP designation in the U.S. and Europe.
FITT has also awarded honorary CITP|FIBP designations to several notable figures in international trade, including former Canadian Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister [[John Manley]], Canadian Chamber of Commerce CEO [[Perrin Beatty]], Governor of the [[Bank of Canada]] [[Stephen Poloz]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eshaabrol.com/tag/citp-designation/|title=CITP Designation {{!}} Entrepreneur Journal|website=eshaabrol.com|access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://smith.queensu.ca/emails/poloz.php|title=QBC Ottawa featuring Stephen Poloz|website=smith.queensu.ca|access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref> and former Canadian [[Minister of International Trade (Canada)|Minister of International Trade]] [[Stockwell Day]].{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}

'''Sir Gerrard Jude "Gerry" Robinson''' (born 23 October 1948, [[Dunfanaghy]], [[County Donegal]], [[Ireland]]) is an Irish-born British business executive and television presenter. He is the former non-executive Chairman of [[Allied Domecq]] and the ex-Chairman/chief executive of [[Granada plc|Granada]].
==Early life== The ninth of 10 children born to Anthony and Elizabeth Robinson, an Irish father and a [[Scotland|Scottish]] mother, Robinson moved with his family to England from [[County Donegal]] in his early teens. He briefly trained to become a [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] priest at [[Castle Head, Grange-over-Sands|St. Mary's Seminary]] of the [[Holy Ghost Fathers]] at Castlehead, [[Grange-over-Sands]], [[Lancashire]]. He began a career in accounting in 1965 as a clerk with the [[Matchbox (brand)|Matchbox Toys]] company. While with the firm, he progressed through various accounting roles to become Chief Management Accountant in 1974. He also, during that time, qualified as an Associate Chartered Management Accountant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.personallyspeakingbureau.com/speaker/gerry-robinson-sir/|title=Gerry Robinson, Sir - Personally Speaking Bureau|accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>
==Career== In 1974, he left Matchbox to work for [[Lex Vehicle Leasing]] as a management accountant. He then rose through the company before being appointed finance director. In 1980, he joined the UK franchise of [[Coca-Cola]], owned at that time by [[Grand Metropolitan]]. In 1983 he was appointed managing director of Grand Metropolitan's international services division. In 1987 he led the successful £163m management buyout of the loss-making contract services and catering division of [[Compass Group]], known as Compass Caterers. He joined [[Granada plc|Granada]] as CEO in 1991, and soon ousted Granada's chairman, [[David Plowright]] in 1992, which led [[John Cleese]] to call Robinson "an upstart caterer ".<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1527549/David-Plowright.html|title=David Plowright obituary|publisher=''The Telegraph''|date=30 August 2006|accessdate=17 July 2011}}</ref>
Robinson steered the company through various mergers, and hostile takeovers including [[London Weekend Television]] (1993) and [[Forte Group]] (1996). In 1999 Robinson was the subject of a biography, ''Lord of the Dance'', written by business journalist [[William Kay (journalist)|William Kay]], and published by Orion Business Books {{ISBN|0752810480}}. In 2005 he made an unsuccessful attempt to oust Doug Flynn as CEO of [[Rentokil Initial]] and install himself as Executive chairman for a 5% stake in the company, then valued at £56M. {{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
==Television== Robinson's first foray into broadcasting was a revival of the [[BBC]]'s [[Troubleshooter (TV series)|''Troubleshooter'']] show, originally fronted by Sir [[John Harvey-Jones]] in the early 1990s. Titled ''I'll Show Them Who's Boss'' and co-produced by the [[Open University]], in 2004 he went into struggling businesses to try to turn them round by advice and mentoring.
In January 2007 following a similar format, he presented a three-part series, ''[[Can Gerry Robinson Fix the NHS?]]'' as he attempted to reduce waiting lists at [[Rotherham NHS Foundation Trust|Rotherham General Hospital]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.open2.net/nhs/about_the_series.html|title=BBC/OU Open2.net, "Can Gerry Robinson Fix The NHS?"|publisher=Open2.net|date=|accessdate= 14 July 2009}}</ref> He returned a year later for a sequel, ''Can Gerry Robinson Fix the NHS? One Year On''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.open2.net/nhs/oneyearon/oneyearonsummary.html|title=BBC/OU Open2.net – Can Gerry Robinson Fix The NHS? One Year On|publisher=Open2.net|date=22 November 2007|accessdate=14 July 2009}}</ref> In December 2009, Robinson presented a programme in a similar format entitled ''Can Gerry Robinson Fix Dementia Care Homes?''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Can Gerry Robinson Fix Dementia Care Homes?|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00pf0s2|publisher=BBC|accessdate=22 January 2014|author=British Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref>
In June 2009 he presented a special edition of ''[[The Money Programme]]'' entitled ''Gerry Robinson's Car Crash'' investigating the history and future of the [[British motor industry]]. He regularly appears on British TV as a celebrity businessman.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1831101/bio IMDb bio]</ref> In July 2009 he started a TV series called ''Gerry's Big Decision'', in which he reviews struggling companies and decides whether it is worth investing his own money to save them. From 14 January – 18 February 2011 he presented [[BBC2]] show ''Can't Take It with You'', which helps people to write their [[will (law)|will]]s.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00xk532]</ref>
==Other affiliations== Robinson also served as chairman of the [[Arts Council England]] for six years from 1998, in which capacity he was one of the many victims of a spoof by British comedian [[Ali G]].<ref>[http://gerry-robinson-news.newslib.com Gerry Robinson official website]</ref>
==Personal life== Robinson has divorced and remarried and has four children. He lives in Raphoe,Co Donegal <ref>http://www.oakfieldpark.com/ Oakfield Park</ref> ; he established a botanical garden with a narrow gauge railway – the Difflin Lake Railway – which is open to the public.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2007/10/07/story27146.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214073506/http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2007/10/07/story27146.asp |archivedate=14 December 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Politics== Although originally a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] supporter, he supported [[Tony Blair]] and starred in a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] [[party political broadcast|election broadcast]], saying that ''"... frankly, there's only one party that can represent Britain best, getting business right, and that's New Labour"''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardianlies.com/Granada%20TV/page3.html|title=Granada TV Part Two: Comrades at the Top|publisher=GuardianLies.com|accessdate=14 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090911030207/http://www.guardianlies.com/Granada%20TV/page3.html|archivedate=11 September 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In June 2008, Robinson was one of four Labour donors who expressed their concerns with [[Gordon Brown]]'s leadership and stated he would not be contributing any more money to the Labour Party until there was a change of leader. He had donated some £70,000 to the party between 2001 and 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7479840.stm|title=Labour donor says Brown must go|publisher=BBC News|date=29 June 2008|accessdate=14 July 2009}}</ref>
==Honours== He was knighted in the [[2004 New Year Honours]] List.
