'''Silvio Werner Denz''' (born 14 September 1956 in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]]) is a Swiss entrepreneur and collector of wine and art, currently living in Switzerland. He worked for various companies in Switzerland and the United States in finance, retail and marketing.<ref>Valli Marie-Pierre. [http://www.lemonde.fr/journalelectronique/donnees/libre/20140411/index.html?cahier=LIV "Silvio Denz épouse son temps"], ''[[Le Monde]]'', Paris, 2014-04-11 2014. Retrieved 2014-11-05.</ref> He now operates mainly in the fields of luxury goods and wine. The Swiss business magazine ''Bilanz'' <ref>https://www.bilanz.ch/people/300-reichste</ref> ranks him among the 300 wealthiest Swiss citizens and, more recently, among the 100 most important figures of the Swiss economy.<ref>https://www.bilanz.ch/people/luxus</ref>
==Entrepreneur==
===Perfume, cosmetics=== In 1980 Silvio Denz took over the management of [[Zurich]]-based Alrodo AG,<ref>{{cite web|author=Kolesnikov-Jessop Sonia |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/01/business/international/covering-the-skill-basics-at-big-companies.html?_r=0 |title=Covering the Skill Basics at Big Companies |publisher=International New York Times |date=2014-09-01 |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref> at that time was owned by his father and uncle. Initially with eight employees, the company purchased perfumes and cosmetics for imported perfumery retailers. After acquiring all the equity in Alrodo in 1984, he built up the company over the next 20 years to become Switzerland's largest perfumery chain, with 120 branches. Between 1980 and 2000, the number of employees rose from 8 to 800. In 2000 Denz sold Alrodo to the French perfumery chain Marionnaud.<ref>{{cite web|author=Carole Bellemare |url= http://www.lefigaro.fr/decideurs/nomination/2015/10/21/33002-20151021ARTFIG00429-silvio-denz-l-esthete-et-epicurienqui-redonne-du-lustre-a-lalique.php |title=Silvio Denz, l'esthète et épicurienqui redonne du lustre à Lalique |publisher=Le Figaro |date=2015-10-21 |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref> In the same year he founded Lalique Group (formerly known as Art & Fragrance) specializing in the creation, production and marketing of perfume and cosmetic brands such as Perfumes [[Alain Delon]], [[Parfums Grès]], Perfumes Lalique, Jaguar Fragrances, Bentley Fragrances and Ultrasun.<ref>Bilanz 31 May 2005; "Silvio Denz: Rastloser Schlossherr"; by Corinne Amacher</ref> The company has been listed on the stock exchange since 2007. It was first listed on the BX Berne eXchange and since June 2018 the Group has been listed on SIX Swiss Exchange. ===Luxury=== Silvio Denz accumulated the world's largest private collection of vintage perfume bottles designed by [[René Lalique]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Samantha Brooks |url= http://robbreport.com/Art-Collectibles/Crystal-Revelations |title= Crystal revelations |publisher=Robb Report |date=2010-11-10 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Sonia Kolesnikov-Jessop |url= http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/998924/the-collector-silvio-denz-and-his-lalique-glass-menagerie |title= The Collector: Silvio Denz and his Lalique Glass Menagerie |publisher=Blouinartinfo.com |date=2014-01-03 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> comprising over 650 original pieces.<ref>Watch Your Time, supplément Montres du Monde, page 15, 11 April 2014, Marie-Pierre Valli</ref> In 2008 the company acquired the French crystalware house Lalique S.A. The group became profitable again after being restructured, with branding focused on art, decorative items, interior design, jewellery, perfume and hospitality.<ref>Le Point, 1st January 2015, Marine de la Horie, „L’art et la matière“</ref> Co-branding projects were developed between Lalique and various other luxury brands (including [[Bentley]], [[The Macallan]] and [[Steinway & Sons]]). Collaborations were also signed with artists such as [[Zaha Hadid]], [[Jean-Michel Jarre]], [[Damien Hirst]], and [[Elton John]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Emily Adams |url= http://issuu.com/runwildmedia/docs/mayf_nov_15 |title= The Butterfly Effect |publisher=The Mayfair Magazine |date=2015-11-01 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> resulting in collections for the company, in some cases. In 2011, the Lalique museum in Wingen-sur-Moder ([[Alsace]]) opened to display more than 650 pieces designed by [[René Lalique]] and his successors, including jewellery, crystal and decorative glass.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eve M. Kahn |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/24/arts/design/among-antiques-lalique-snuffboxes-and-soviet-film-posters.html?_r=0 |title=Suddenly, Lalique is back in Vogue |publisher=New York Times |date=2011-06-11 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> Denz loaned 230 pieces from his personal collection, mostly perfume bottles.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.musee-lalique.com/en/collections-presented-mus%C3%A9e-lalique |title=The collections presented at the Musée Lalique |publisher=Musée Lalique |accessdate=2016-01-08}}</ref> Denz also converted René Lalique's villa in Wingen-sur-Moder into a luxury hotel and restaurant, which opened in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=Carol Lewis |url= http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/property/interiors/article4586117.ece |title=Like the furniture? Then buy it|publisher=The Times |date=2015-10-16|accessdate=2016-01-06}}</ref>
===Wine=== In 1994 Silvio Denz, along with Franz Wermuth and five other partners, founded Les Grand Vins Wermuth S.A., now split into Denz Weine (distribution) and Wermuth Auktionen AG (auctions)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wermuth.ch |title=Les Grands Vins Wermuth SA, Weinhandel, Weinauktionen |publisher=Wermuth.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> in Zurich. In 1998, acting with the same partners, he bought the Clos d'Agon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.closdagon.com |title=Clos d'Agon |publisher=Closdagon.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> estate on the [[Costa Brava]], which is overseen by the oenologist [[Peter Sisseck]] ([[Dominio Pingus]]).
In 2005, on the recommendation of his friend Count Stephan von Neipperg ([[Château Canon-la-Gaffelière]] and [[La Mondotte]]), Denz bought the Château Faugères estate, six kilometers east of [[Saint Emilion]]. Faugères, which has 30 employees,<ref>http://www.châteaufaugeres.com{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> comprises three vineyards: Château Faugères, Château Péby Faugères, both lying in the Saint-Emilion appellation, and Château Cap-de-Faugères in Côtes de Castillion. In 2010, he and Peter Sisseck took over the vineyard of Château Rocheyron in Saint-Emilion. The estates in [[Bordeaux]] cover a total of 120 hectares.<ref>Schweizerische Weinzeitung; Ausgabe 3 März 2012;"Silvio Denz: Unternehmer und leidenschaftlicher Sammler von Weingütern"</ref> Silvio Denz also owns the Montepeloso winery in Italy (which he acquired with Fabio Chiarelotto in 2007).
The winery at Château Faugères was designed by the architect [[Mario Botta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.botta.ch |title=mario botta architetto |publisher=Botta.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref><ref>Sonntagszeitung; GenussTrend 18 October 2009</ref> He describes his creation as a "cathedral of wine".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/ |title=Actualité à la Une |publisher=Le Monde.fr |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> Using modern technology coupled with traditional methods, such as gravity-filling, the wines are aged in oak barrels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/cash-tv/video/cash-tv-vom-01-04-2012?id=f31eada9-0218-4cc3-bb6e-f8263bcbfa36 |title=cash TV vom 01.04.2012 - cash TV - TV - SRF Player - Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen |publisher=Srf.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225201746/http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/cash-tv/video/cash-tv-vom-01-04-2012?id=f31eada9-0218-4cc3-bb6e-f8263bcbfa36 |archivedate=25 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2012 Château Faugères and Château Péby Faugères were awarded the status of Grand Cru Classé of Saint-Emilion. According to the wine critic [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]], Château Péby Faugères today ranks among the finest Bordeaux wines.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.erobertparker.com/entrance.aspx |title=The Independent Consumer's Guide to Fine Wine |publisher=eRobertParker.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819083230/https://www.erobertparker.com/entrance.aspx |archivedate=19 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wineinvestment.com/wine-blog/2015/06/parker-s-top-100-2005-bordeaux-wines/|title=Parker's Top 100 2005 Bordeaux Wines |publisher=wineinvestment.com}}</ref> In 2015 the influential Parker's Wine Buyer's Guide rated Château Péby Faugères Vintage 2005 100/100.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.comptoirdesmillesimes.com/blog/les-meilleurs-vins-robert-parker |title= Les 300 vins ayant obtenu la note de 100/100 par Robert Parker |publisher=Le blog de comptoir de millésimes |date=2015-09-25 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> In February 2014, Silvio Denz acquired [[Château Lafaurie-Peyraguey]], one of the few Premiers Grands Crus Classés of 1855 and one of the oldest vineyards in Sauternes. Silvio Denz's wine businesses are held in Art & Terroir.
On September 17, 2017, Silvio Denz was inducted as a Saint-Emilion Jurat.<ref>https://en.vins-saint-emilion.com/about/jurade-saint-emilion Sain-Emilion Jurat</ref> The Jurade of Saint-Emilion currently consists of 127 Jurats and more than 3000 Saint-Emilion wine ambassadors worldwide. In October 2017, he was awarded a Special Jury Prize from Fond’Action Alsace <ref>Fond’Action Alsace http://www.fondaction-alsace.com/les-laureats.html Fond’Action Alsace</ref> for his active involvement in the Alsace region. In the same month, he then went on to receive the Guillon d’Or award from the Guillon d’Or award,<ref>Confrérie du Guillon http://www.guillon.ch/fr/Activites/Guillon-d-Or-CDC/Guillon-d-Or-CDC.html</ref> a Vaudois wine brotherhood founded in 1954, commending his passion and performance in the world of wine.
===Property=== In 2003 Silvio Denz entered the real estate business in London. Working with local partners, he buys, renovates, and then resells traditional town houses in Mayfair, Knightsbridge and Kensington.<ref>Financial Times 1/2 August 2009; "Art and architecture are my passions"; by Rebecca Duke</ref>
==Collector==
===Pictures=== Silvio Denz collects works of art via his company Art & Trade.<ref>Handelszeitung/Special/Casa/Nr38/22–28 September 2010; "Schlossherr Silvio Denz"; Esther Bullmann {{dead link|date=October 2014}}</ref>
===Wine=== He has been buying vintage wines for over 30 years, mainly from Bordeaux. His private cellar contains more than 35,000 bottles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/998924/the-collector-silvio-denz-and-his-lalique-glass-menagerie |title=The Collector: Silvio Denz and his Lalique Glass Menagerie |publisher=blouinartinfo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-02}}</ref>
===Crystal=== His interest in perfume bottles dates from his time at Alrodo. Today, he is the owner of the world's largest private collection of bottles by the celebrated French glass artist [[René Lalique]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/cash-tv/video/cash-tv-vom-07-10-2012?id=fdd387ca-69b5-4d55-8ecc-ee8fb9dac01c |title=cash TV vom 07.10.2012 - cash TV - TV - SRF Player - Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen |publisher=Srf.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref><ref>Dernières Nouvelles d'Alsace (DNA) 2 July 2011; "Inauguration du Musée Lalique/Déja une référence"; by Jean Luc Will</ref>
==Awards and Memberships== Member of the Board of Directors Lindt & Sprüngli (2018)<ref>http://www.lindt-spruengli.com/investors/events-presentations/annual-general-meeting/</ref>; Member "Chaîne des Rôtisseurs", Alsace (2018) <ref>http://france.chainedesrotisseurs.com/?lang=en</ref>; Saint-Emilion Jurat, The Jurade of Saint-Emilion 17 September (2017);<ref>https://en.vins-saint-emilion.com/about/jurade-saint-emilion</ref> Special Jury Prize, Fond’Action Alsace (2017);<ref>http://www.fondaction-alsace.com/les-laureats.html</ref> The Guillon d’Or award, Confrérie du Guillon (2017);<ref>http://www.guillon.ch/fr/Activites/Guillon-d-Or-CDC/Guillon-d-Or-CDC.html</ref> Member "Keepers of the Quaich", Scotland(2015);<ref>https://www.keepersofthequaich.co.uk/</ref> Honorary member, Confrérie Saint-Etienne d'Alsace (2017);<ref>http://www.confrerie-st-etienne.com/fr/</ref> Member "Club Prosper Montagne" (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.club-prosper-montagne.ch/default.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110174334/http://www.club-prosper-montagne.ch/default.aspx |archivedate=10 January 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

'''Supplier risk management''' (SRM) is an evolving discipline in operations management for manufacturers, retailers, financial services companies and government agencies where the organization is highly dependent on suppliers to achieve business objectives.
The complexity and globally outsourced nature of today’s supply chains combined with the practice of optimization techniques such as lean and just-in-time manufacturing in order to improve efficiency has increased supply chain vulnerabilities to even minor supply disruptions. While these models have allowed companies to reduce overall costs and expand quickly into new markets, they also expose the company to the risk of a supplier suddenly going bankrupt, closing operations, data breach<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.preparis.com/blog/third-party-vendors-greatest-cyber-risk/|title=Third Party Vendors Could Be Your Greatest Cyber Risk - Preparis|website=www.preparis.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-31}}</ref> or being acquired. Among the several types of supply disruptions, most severe are those that have a relatively low probability of occurrence with a very high severity of impact when they do occur. While such risks cannot be eliminated, however, its severity can be reduced.
==Objectives== To overcome these challenges, companies mitigate [[Supply chain risk management|supply chain interruptions]] and reduce risk with strategies and tactics that address supplier-centric risk at multiple stages in the relationship:
* On boarding: Bringing suppliers into the operation with registration that includes: ** A centralized supplier registration portal ** Integration of third party performance, financial data and predictive indicators into the supplier profile * Monitoring for stability beyond financial data, including: ** Criminal and terrorists (i.e. [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]]) ties and operational performance ** Visibility into potential disruptions caused by geopolitical threats, acts of nature, etc. * Cultivating strategic supplier relationships for the long-term: ** Leverage supplier scorecards for continuous improvement ** Establish and use benchmarks for measuring supplier performance ** Creating a system for collaboration and supplier development * Establish control across the extended enterprise: ** Create integrated supplier networks ** Extend performance management benchmarks to second and third tier suppliers
== Supplier risk in recession and recovery ==
In 2008-2009, manufacturers experienced the startling speed at which suppliers can move from stability to shutting down operations. The devastating impact of a crucial supplier failure has moved [[risk management]] from add-on service to mission-critical. With a new focus on risk management, manufacturers have seen value whether the economy is stagnant or thriving.
With a transparent, accessible and comprehensive set of supplier information, manufacturers have been able to monitor suppliers for behavioral changes which contribute to overall stability, including: * Changes in the supplier’s management team * EPA violations * OSHA incidents * Quality issues * Noticeable lags in response time to inquiries * OFAC violations
Changes in any of these conditions can be defined as parameters for raising an alert. For example, a financially stable supplier may in fact be about to lose it [[CEO]] to retirement – which may cause issues within the management team. Early visibility into that change gives the manufacturer time to ensure it doesn’t negatively affect customers.
Based on the criticality of the supplier and the nature of the alert received, the manufacturer can then choose to take necessary action, such as calling or visiting the supplier, increasing monitoring, or moving towards terminating the relationship with the supplier and finding a replacement.
== Benefits ==
Reducing supplier risk can: * Give insight to manufacturers to create defensive and offensive strategies that turn risk into a [[Competitiveness|competitive advantage]]. * Help determine whether or not it is beneficial for a company to conduct a customer intervention and know in advance what the potential outcomes might be for an intervention. * Improve competitive position in the market. * Lower supplier costs. * Position manufacturers to better address customer needs by addressing supplier vulnerabilities before they become apparent. * Prevent loss of customer's trust due to [https://www.upguard.com/breaches/topic/data-breaches data exposure] or [http://fortune.com/2016/09/26/swift-hack/ systems being hacked].

'''Tan Yu''' ({{zh|t=鄭周敏|p=Zhèng Zhōumǐn}}; April 5, 1927 – 12 March 2002) was a [[China|Chinese]] philanthropist and businessman who founded the Asiaworld Internationale Group <ref>{{cite web|last=Philippe|first=Lasserre|title=Players in Asia-Pacific: A Profile|url=http://www.insead.edu/facultyresearch/research/doc.cfm?did=2516|publisher=INSEAD Euro-Asia Centre}}</ref> and established the KTTI Foundation, which provided scholarships to and supported the education of thousands of young students. In 1997, Forbes estimated his net worth to be about $7 billion. He was placed amongst the top 10 in the world on the Forbes List of World Billionaires 1997,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-07-01/business/fi-20274_1_bill-gates | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Bill Gates Tops Forbes List of Billionaires | date=1996-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19960701&slug=2337273 | work=The Seattle Times | title=Gates Stays On Top Of Forbes' Richest List -- Asian Tycoons Move Up In Rankings | date=1996-07-01}}</ref> making him the wealthiest man in the Philippines.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bay-Hansen|first=C.D.|title=Power Geopolitics in the Pacific Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Paj2IkbdgmIC&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68&dq=tanyu+forbes+1996&source=bl&ots=A-3jc0k6YL&sig=CErWudG2TXeJKjER6MyhiRTayeg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t0ynT7POCISI6AHezu3dBA&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=snippet&q=tan%20yu&f=false|publisher=Inkwater Press}}</ref> Some projects were affected by the 1997 Financial Crisis.<ref>{{cite news|title=Forbes Asia Financial Report|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/1998/0706/6201196a.html|newspaper=Forbes Magazine}}</ref>
==Early life== Originally from [[Fujian]] province in [[China]], Yu and his family moved to the Philippines at a young age. He began making a living in [[Camarines Norte]] through selling bread buns in the streets and doing some fishing. He graduated from [[University of St. La Salle]] in [[Bacolod City]], and in 1997, received an honorary doctorate of science degree from the [[New Jersey Institute of Technology]].<ref>{{cite news|title=CNN Asiaweek interview|url=http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0202/biz2.html|newspaper=CNN Asiaweek|date=2000-11-30|access-date=2012-02-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109084859/http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0202/biz2.html#|archive-date=2014-01-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> By the age of 18, he had established a successful textile business.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tycoon, Philanthropist Tan Yu dies at 75|url=http://www.newsflash.org/2002/03/hl/hl015377.htm|newspaper=Philippine Headline News}}</ref>
==Business Interests== During his lifetime, he planned to develop [[Fuga]] and [[Barit]], two northernmost islands in the Philippines, into a resort in the Pacific for businessmen and tourists.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0202/biz1.html |title = From Backwater to Fantasy Isle: Filipino-Chinese Tycoon Makes an Audacious Move |newspaper = CNN Asiaweek |accessdate = 2008-08-19 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110927035522/http://cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0202/biz1.html# |archive-date = 2011-09-27 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> Under the company Asiaworld, he possessed more land in the Philippines than the government, as well as possessing overseas assets in the form of property,<ref>{{cite news|title=Taiwanese Billionaire Tan Yu building homes in Houston|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1999_3140810/taiwanese-billionaire-building-homes-in-sharpstown.html|newspaper=Houston Chronicle}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> hotels<ref>{{cite news|title=Forbes Asia Financial Report|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/1998/0706/6201196a.html|newspaper=Forbes Magazine}}</ref> and banks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tan Yu's $12 Billion Empire|url=http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0202/biz5.html|newspaper=CNN Asiaweek|access-date=2008-08-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204123014/http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0202/biz5.html#|archive-date=2009-02-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
His key holdings included the Asiaworld Plaza Hotel in Taiwan, over 200 Hectares of prime land in [[Manila Bay]] and the Islands of Fuga and Barit.<ref>{{cite book|last=Studwell|first=Joe|title=Asian Godfathers - Money and Power in Hong Kong and South East Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=720iFSxkII8C&printsec=frontcover&redir_esc=y#v=snippet&q=%22tan%20yu%22&f=false|publisher=Atlantic Monthly Press}}</ref>
==Personal life and death== Tan Yu died of [[heart failure]] in [[Houston, Texas]], in 2002 at the age of 75. [[Jose de Venecia]], the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Philippines, commended his achievements as a great businessman and as a philanthropist, for providing jobs to a number of Philippine people.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jose de Venecia Jr. mourns the loss the tycoon|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=153811&publicationSubCategoryId=63|newspaper=Philippines Star}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He was posthumously honored with the Dr. Jose P. Rizal Award for Excellence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.manilatimes.net/others/rizal.html |title=2008 Dr. Jose P. Rizal Awards for Excellence; Search for Outstanding Chinese-Filipinos |publisher=The Manila Times Internet Edition |accessdate=2008-08-28 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080419034307/http://www.manilatimes.net/others/rizal.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-04-19}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{underlinked|date=December 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=January 2012}} {{technical|date=July 2016}} }} '''Tradespace''' has three related meanings: #As a multi-variant mathematical playspace used for identifying the optimal boundary spaces (the [[Pareto frontier]]) where the multiple variants have strong interdependencies. The term, Tradespace, is a combination of the words “trade-off” and “playspace”, where “trade-off” indicates the method of traversing the Tradespace in search of the optimal boundary space (e.g., trading off a cost in one cost center (variant A) for a cost in another cost center (variant B)). Tradespace analysis is used in this context by NASA, DARPA and MIT for analyzing the complex resource, costs and provisioning involved in large projects with multiple stakeholders and multiple objectives. #As a collection of processes spanning multiple organizations. “Tradespace” in this context is used to distinguish the difference between '''intra'''-corporate process management and '''inter'''-corporate process management (although it may include (not exclusively) intra-corporate, inter-departmental processes). This type of Tradespace shares business processes and human resources across the system resulting in a collection of business processes spanning corporate or departmental boundaries. The term Tradespace was first applied in this context in 2003 by QBOS, Inc. as a way of signifying the relevance of the term in its above context to the search for equilibria (the [[Pareto frontier]]) in a collection of processes spanning multiple organizations where those organizations each have their own seven-sigma core objectives. The relevance of the term as a collection of inter-corporate processes to its meaning as a multi-variant interdependent playspace becomes very apparent when observing organizations working together in a Tradespace via processes put in place between the organizations. Their at-first-glance independent objectives take on an interdependency similar to the multi-variant models in the mathematical use of the term. Thus, the very act of creating inter-corporate processes creates an interdependency that must be explored and managed in order to reach an equilibrium state that is stable, resilient and maximizes opportunity and ROI for the participant organizations (see Tradespace Management System). Multiple Tradespaces of this type may aggregate to form larger Tradespaces of this type. #In a financial sense as an environment for supporting inter-corporate financial exchange transactions. This form of the term was instantiated by NextSet Software, Inc. in 2000.
Multiple Tradespaces of context type 2 or 3, above, may aggregate to form larger Tradespaces of the same type. Merging Tradespaces of both types (2 and 3) results in an [[business ecosystem|eco-system]]. Distinctions between Tradespaces and eco-systems include:
#Tradespaces can give rise to strong eco-systems but not the other way around and #By focusing on either the analysis of inter-corporate processes (context 2 above) or the analysis of inter-corporate funds exchange (context 3 above), Tradespaces form natural boundary interfaces matching the [[cash flow / provisioning interface]] and thus protect against the anomalies that can arise in a poorly designed cash-flow/provisioning interface. Eco-systems that are not designed on a Tradespace foundation model first, run the risk of dissolution due to anomalies created by the [[cash flow / provisioning interface]].
The term Tradespace has the following trademark registrations against it: *By QBOS, Inc. **Serial Number: 77453425 (Filed: Apr 21, 2008) **Registration Number: 3769751 (Apr 6, 2010) **Goods and Services Description (Intl Class 042): “Facilitating the exchange of needed information to provision of business goods and services via the Internet” *By NextSet Software Inc. **Serial Number: 76119221 (Filed: Aug 30, 2000) **Registration Number: 2714085 (May 6, 2003) **Goods and Services Description (Intl Class 009): “Computer e-commerce software which enables users to participate in electronic exchange transactions and auctions, via a global computer network” **Goods and Services Description (Intl Class 042): “Computer software development services for others in the field of electronic business exchange transactions and auctions”

[[File:Vitaliy Antonov.jpg|thumbnail]] '''Antonov Vitaliy Borysovyvch''' (born December 12, 1962 in [[Stryi]], [[Lviv Oblast]]) is a Ukrainian businessman, head of the supervisory board of Concern Galnaftogaz (OKKO filling station network), head of the supervisory board of the Universalna insurance company, and president of the Universalna Investment Group. He is an Honorary General Consul of Lithuania in Lviv and has a Ph.D in Economics. Education He studied at the Stryi School #4 in 1970-1978. He graduated from the Ternopil Financial-Economic Institute with honors with a specialization in “finance and credit” in 1988. He defended a dissertation on the topic “Activation of the Attraction of Foreign Direct investment into Ukraine’s Economy in the Condition of Global Competition” and received a scientific degree, a Ph.D. in Economics in 2011.
== Career == In school, Vitaliy Antonov was fond of [[rock climbing]] and later [[mountain climbing]]; his first workplaces were connected to these hobbies. He was the head of the mountain climbing/tourist club in his home town in 1988-1990; he was the head of the Lviv Oblast rescue service of the [[Red Cross]] in Stryi in 1990-1992. Vitaliy Antonov started his own business in 1992. He became the director of the private company Karat, which conducted wholesaling of various groups of products. Over time, one of the main specializations of this company was trading oil products. Vitaliy Antonov became the president of OJSC Galnaftogaz in 1995 and head of the supervisory board of OJSC Galnaftogaz in 2001. Vitaliy Antonov opened the first OKKO brand filling station in Stryi in 1999. He opened the first large OKKO filling station complex on Zelena Street in Lviv with a store, café and portal car wash in 2000, which became the prototype for the OKKO network’s modern format of filling stations. Vitaliy Antonov has been the president of Universalna Investment Group since 2004, a member of the supervisory board of Concern Khlibprom since 2006 and head of the supervisory board of the Universalna insurance company since 2008. Vitaliy Antonov won top oil & gas company head in the rankings of the Top-100 managers of Ukraine for three years in a row in 2010-2012, which was prepared by InvestGazeta and Ekonomika publishing house. He was one of the three top managers in Ukraine in 2011 and top manager in the category “Salesperson and Marketer” in 2012 by the aforementioned publication, Top-100. According to results of internet voting on the portal of the newspaper Delo in 2012, Vitaliy Antonov was third in the national rating “Responsible Leader.” For the first time, in 2013, he was named one of the most influential people in the country according to the magazine Korrespondent, taking 66th place. According to the magazine Forbes Ukraine, Vitaliy Antonov was 40th in the Top-100 richest people of Ukraine in 2013. He took 42nd place in magazine Korrespondent’s “Golden 100” in 2013.
== Other activities == Vitaliy Antonov headed the Ukrainian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs’s commission on issues of the fuel-energy sector of Ukraine in 1999-2000. He was a member of the Council of Investors under the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine in 2009-2010. He became a member of the Council on the Issue of Stimulating Investments and Entrepreneurial Activity under the Minister of Revenue and Duties of Ukraine in 2013. Vitaliy Antonov has been an Honorary Consul of Lithuania in Lviv and Lviv Oblast since 1999 and Honorary General Consul of Lithuania in Lviv since 2007. He has been the head of the Taras Shevchenko Ukrainian-Lithuanian Fund since 2001. Vitaliy Antonov believes that the Lithuania’s experience with transforming society from post-totalitarian into a free and open society is very valuable for the Ukrainian national project since both countries have a common history and similar mentalities. Vitaliy Antonov became one of the founders of the Lviv Business School of the Ukrainian Catholic University in 2008. Vitaliy Antonov is a candidate in sports in mountain climbing and rock climbing. He is fluent in Ukrainian, Russian and English languages. In 2016 elected as a member of Ivan Franko Lviv National University Supervisory Board
== Awards == * State Order of Ukraine “For Merit” III Degree * Lithuanian Government Award – “Millennium Star of Lithuania” Order * “Christ’s Birth 2000” Order of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchy * Award from the Head of the Ukrainian Greek-Catholic Church
== Family status == Antonov is divorced; he has two daughters (born in 1985 and 1993) and a son (born in 2003).

The license is held by the Beasley Media Group, LLC, part of the [[Beasley Broadcast Group]], Inc.[http://fjallfoss.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/cdbsmenu.hts?context=25&appn=101202509&formid=323&fac_num=0 FCC Station Ownership database] The station carries financial news from [[Bloomberg Radio]] with some local news, weather and traffic reports. WRCA's programming is also heard on [[Broadcast translator|FM translator]] '''W291CZ''' (106.1 MHz) and on the HD2 channel of sister station [[WBOS]]. ==History== [[File:WRCA1330.png|thumb|left|Logo for the station prior to November 15, 2016]] The station began operating as '''WCRB''' on January 30, 1948, owned by Theodore Jones's [[Charles River Broadcasting]] (hence the W'''CRB''' [[call sign|call letters]]). WCRB was originally a community radio station for [[Waltham, Massachusetts]], before switching to a [[classical music]] format a few years later. An FM [[simulcast]] was added in 1954, [[WCRB]]-FM. As FM broadcasting became more popular for music listening, the AM station ceased simulcasting WCRB-FM's classical format in 1975 and became '''WHET''', programming a [[big band]]/[[adult standards]] format from 1975 until 1978, and then a short run as a [[beautiful music]] outlet. Sales of the station to various owners led to formats such as [[country music]] '''WDLW''' for most of the 1980s, and then ''"Showbiz Radio"'' '''WRCA''' (standing for "Radio, Comedy, and Arts") in 1990 before the station began [[brokered programming|leasing time]] to ethnic broadcasters in 1991 with the WRCA [[call sign]] retained. The current owners, the [[Beasley Broadcast Group]], took over in 2000 from the ADD Radio Group. The station's long time [[transmitter]] site in Waltham was discontinued in 2007 when WRCA became one of three AM stations to share a rebuilt transmitter facility at the original site of [[WUNR|WBOS]] [[AM 1600]] on Sawmill Brook Parkway in [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]]. This site is now used by stations on 1200, 1330 and 1600 kHz. WRCA's [[city of license]] changed from Waltham to Watertown in 2007, and the power increased to 25,000 watts daytime, 17,000 watts nighttime. In addition to ethnic programming, WRCA had broadcast [[Northeastern Huskies men's ice hockey]] games. Following Beasley's acquisition of [[Greater Media]], WRCA went [[dark (broadcasting)|dark]] on November 15, 2016, as it moved to new studios; it returned in May 2017 with a simulcast of "Boston's Irish Channel", the HD2 channel of sister station [[WBQT (FM)|WBQT]], as it was believed that WRCA was in the process of signal testing. The station was also paired with an [[FM broadcasting|FM]] [[broadcast relay station|translator]], '''W291CZ''' (licensed to [[Boston]]) at 106.1 [[Hertz|MHz]].[http://radio-locator.com/info/W291CZ-FX Radio-Locator] On July 3, 2017, [[Bloomberg L.P.]] and Beasley announced that WRCA/W291CZ would begin carrying [[Bloomberg Radio]] programming (which moved over from [[WXKS (AM)|WXKS]]) beginning the following day. Concurrently, the HD2 channel of [[WBOS]] began to simulcast WRCA's programming.[https://radioinsight.com/headlines/118668/bloomberg-moving-1330106-1-boston/ Bloomberg Radio Moving to 1330/106.1 Boston] ==Translator== {{RadioTranslators | callsign = WRCA | width = | call1 = W291CZ | freq1 = 106.1 | fid1 = 144592 | watts1 = 99 | class1 = D | city1 = Boston, Massachusetts | coord1 = {{coord|42|20|57.00|N|71|4|31.00|W|region:US-MA_type:landmark|name=W291CZ}} | notes1 = }} ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite web |url = http://www.bostonradio.org/stations/60695.html |title = The Boston Radio Dial: WRCA (AM) |work = The Archives at BostonRadio.org |date = 2005-03-27 |accessdate = January 20, 2006 }} ==External links== *[http://www.bloombergradio.com Official website] {{AM station data|WRCA}} *{{FMQ|W291CZ}} *{{FMXL|W291CZ}} *[http://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/getimportletter_exh.cgi?import_letter_id=80480 FCC History Cards for WDLW (WRCA)] {{Boston Radio}} {{Bloomberg Radio}} {{Beasley Broadcast Group}} [[Category:Watertown, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1948]] [[Category:Radio stations in Boston|RCA]] [[Category:Media in Middlesex County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Beasley Broadcast Group radio stations]] [[Category:Business talk radio stations]] [[Category:Business media in the United States]] {{Massachusetts-radio-station-stub}}
